number of helpful: 16 of 42 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												At first blush, this game appears to be good, wacky, irreverent fun somewhat in the vein of Monty Python. The gameplay is full of original concepts you will find quite literally nowhere else, and I admit, at first I was gripped.The honeymoon period, however, wears off quickly, as the game begins to throw more and more unfair, unbalanced tripe unintuitive gameplay elements that weaken the core experience, and the single-player mode drags fairly quickly; there's only so much some quick satire of history can do for me.If you can pick this up for a song, go for it, but don't expect it to entertain you long. It's a neat experiment, but ultimately I don't feel that it's one that succeeded.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Way too difficult to Control, not incredibly funny, Took me by surprise to have some sort of tower defence when the enemy goes up against you as well, a bit laggy, controls are WAY too sensative, I tapped the D key, nearly turned my Boulder right around, almost a complete 180. Not enough things to destroy, music is bleh, Animations are a bit Flash gamey in cutscenes. I got it for about 2 bucks on sale, Kind of wish I could get a refund, cause now I have to see this game every single time I go into my Library, but that's a Steam thing, Kind of wish there was a thing like steam bucks or something, but anyways, this game also downloaded a lot of stuff on my PC I don't think are needed to even RUN the game. So I am a bit worried, a couple of files in my Computer files named a bunch of random Letters and numbers really, Kind of scared me really.  So Let's Recap.Bleh MusicPoor Animated Cut scenesOversensative controlsUseless Tower defence system cause the CPU is cheapNot enough destructionLame comedyand non-refundable experience. (But that's Steam's Problem really, Serious Steam, Please find some way To get your customers to get refunds! Like store credit for half of what you payed for the game would be ACCEPTABLE In my book!)I do not recommend this game, some people like it, but my expierience is just terrible with this game, I beat the first level and was jumped by the whole tower defence thing, I put down as many towers as possible in tight places. The CPU Just rolled right on through them at high speed, not hitting ANY of em, so yeah, CPU Is cheap.

												Have you ever squashed Leonardo de Caprio with a giant boulder? Have you ever crushed the armies of Dracula the Bat with a huge stone? Have you ever pitted great historical legends like Susaphone of Greek Legend against the likes of Pluto and the Agronites both utilizing the power of equally large rocks? Have you ever been so historically inaccurate that you were accurate because the history books were written by the Wingardium Illumanti? Have you ever failed your history class because your teacher called you out on that â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥t and then you dropped an exporbitant metaphoric structure on said teacher and got away with it?If you did, then you're probably the police then who are just arriving at my home to find that I'VE RIGGED THE ENTIRE BLOCK TO EXPLODE.If not, you're playing Rock of Ages, a delighfully quirky and fast paced strategy/platformer/rock-crushing simulator game and advise you to completely disregard the last paragraph or else you may be burned at the stake like that famous witch, The Crucible.

Posted: October 1, 2012
												Rock of Ages is an interesting riff on the typical strategy game. Your goal is to get your boulder to the enemies gate and crash it down. But before you control your boulder, you and your opponent are given time to set up defenses like catapults (which damage boulders) or Elephants (which can push your boulder off the map). When the set-up time expires, you can control your boulder and try to dodge your enemies defenses to get to their gate. The singleplayer campaign is split with about 90% of these "break the opponents gate" maps and about 10% boss battles, which really don't work as well. The game also has a 2 player VS mode, as well as a race mode where you try to get to a goal as fast as you can. The game also has a cool Monty Python animation style in its cutscenes, and it has some oddball visual humor as well. It works well in Single Player, and the AI is pretty fair, but if you want to get some more legs out of the game it's worth it to play the VS mode with a friend.

												This game is a riot to play with friends! Roll your huge boulder at your enemies gate, smash his peasants and structures for cash. Use cash to build tower, traps, units, or fire projectiles at the enemy ball - or give your rock wings, or armor. Many unique courses, lots of fun traps. AWESOME to 1v1 with friends. Strategy plus good Rock Rolling Control will win the game! $2.49 when 75% off. this game is a no brainer must buy. Tremendously fun. but - a bit hit or miss in terms of connection. my friend and i sometimes take several tries before being able to play a game. BUT ITS WORTH IT.

Posted: April 26, 2014
												Sisyphus, an immortal Greek Titan, has a job to do. For the rest of eternity he must push a giant boulder up a hill in Hades until a magical enchantment causes it to roll back down to the bottom again. Understandably enough, Sisyphus eventually decides this un-life isnât for him and swiftly breaks out of Hades, taking his giant boulder and some Titan buddies with him.Rock of Ages is a hilariously chaotic mixture of Insane Obstacle Course and Tower Defence, alternating between guiding your boulder into the enemy gates to break them down, and building medieval weaponry to stop your rival boulder from breaking your own gates. Itâs a genuine pleasure to watch your hastily erected dynamite finish just in time to blast your opponent completely off-course with white-knuckle timing.As you progress through the campaign by massively interrupting famous European historical events, you unlock more Tower Defence items to stymie your opponents efforts and more rock types to destroy the enemy gates which does an excellent job of keeping the gameplay of Rock of Ages fresh and delightfully experimental; will only using War Mammoths stop your opponent wrecking your gates more than wall after wall of dynamite?Rock of Ages also shines in the cutscenes between levels with both a unique art style and hugely funny direction. Famous characters and events are played out on screen in a 2D mumble-speech cinematic, with the famous opponents (normally accurate, although Plato and Aristotle probably never came back from the dead) highlighted in a massively dramatic way. It brilliantly furthers the light-hearted and joyfully silly theme.It quickly becomes apparent when playing Rock of Ages that it is a game wholeheartedly about the joy of play. Each level is short enough that progress is never too far away and you will never guess what the game is going to throw at you next. With a depth of silliness that will bring a smile to any face Rock of Ages is a pure joy to play and happily provides many hours of shameless fun.

You also are allowed the privilege of engaging in a duel with the Bubonic Plague himself.

												Greatly enjoyed single player mode.  You guide your "rock" down a ramp fraugh with perils to attack the castle at the end and breach the walls.  In between each run, you add obstacles to the path to slow or destroy your opponents ball, for he is trying to breach your castle.  Gets pretty tricky toward the end- both in guiding your ball with agility and adding the right obstacles in the right places.  I suspect the reviewer who said "it comes down to whoever gets 3 balls to the end first" played the game to the end, as that stops being true by halfway through. Posted: March 10, 2014
												What can I say about this game. I didn't expect what I got...maybe that is what I should say. I purchased this game as part of a bundle and started playing it and let me tell you, it is strangely addicting. As I'm sure you're aware, you play as a boulder, rolling through a course, trying to destroy the opponent's gate first and kill them while they are trying to same to you. You lay traps for your opponent as well as they do for you, making this an oddly fun game. There are only two downfalls to this game. One, the game is, for the most part, fairly easy. Sure, it doesn't take much for one to buy and play this game but there isn't much of a challenge for those looking for it, though there is multiplayer. Second, there are collectables in this game: Keys. These keys, early on, are easy to get and put in places which you must creatively think how to get. That being said, the later keys are unfair to get, especially the one on the last level before the final boss. Overall, a solid, easy game which can be enjoyed for a few hours.

Product received for free
												You send a boulder down a twisty slope towards your opponentâs castle, steering and jumping--donât ask how--as you splat flat buildings and little screaming people, bouncing over defences and smacking into the gates. At the same time, your opponent (computer or human) does the same to you. After the rock bashes a chunk off the gate workers start carving another boulder and, in the brief downtime, you place defences like explosives, wind machines, brave doomed elephants and cows. It's more meticulous than I expected. When I'm building traps I'm being rushed, but when racing downhill I'm constantly made to slow down. Still, there's nothing quite like it. The animation, which goes through various periods of art history as you progress, is gorgeous and hilarious. The boss battles arenât a great addition, although defeating Michelangeloâs David by shooting a boulder at hisâ¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥was certainly an experience.

Posted: October 30, 2015
												Pretty simple really, you're a boulder that rolls down a slope smashing things on your way down in an effort to break the enemy gates and squash their leader. Meanwhile an enemy boulder is rolling down your slope trying to do the same thing to you. You need to build defenses such as towers, elephants, airships and ballistae to fend off the enemy boulder whilst simultaneously dodging the enemy's own defenses.There's a campaign mode and a bunch of minigames, it's quite short but there's plenty to unlock and replay, with amusing little cutscenes featuring "Monty Python" style humour. You can also play online, which might add an extra layer of unpredictability that the enemy AI can't replicate.The only gripe I can think of is that the boss battles felt kind of unnecessary and somewhat interrupted the flow of the game. They usually involve some sort of timing mechanic, which can be frustrating until you get the hang of the boss' attack patterns. Thankfully they don't play a major part in the game and most of the content is the regular levels.

Posted: March 3, 2012
												Rock of Ages is a combination of both ball rolling and tower defense with silly humor thrown in. The game plays by giving offense and defense. The offense is rolling a ball, while the defense is setting up structures that will try and stop the opponent. The result is a fun game with a balance on tactics and skill. The game also sports a silly style as shown through the cutscenes. Each historical figure recieves a Pythonesque treatment with cutout graphics and crude animation and almost nonsensical situations. Art periods are spanned, from Greek to Rococo. The style of cutting out historical paintings and drawings is the basis of the game's graphics for 2d pieces, though in gameplay, well made 3d models are used that mimic the art period. Music is mostly famous clasical pieces and original tracks to compliment the historical theme of the game. In addition, extra modes such as Skeeball and Online multiplayer provide extra playability to the game's core. Rock of Ages is a game to enjoy!

Posted: October 1, 2012
												Rock of Ages is an interesting riff on the typical strategy game. Your goal is to get your boulder to the enemies gate and crash it down. But before you control your boulder, you and your opponent are given time to set up defenses like catapults (which damage boulders) or Elephants (which can push your boulder off the map). When the set-up time expires, you can control your boulder and try to dodge your enemies defenses to get to their gate. The singleplayer campaign is split with about 90% of these "break the opponents gate" maps and about 10% boss battles, which really don't work as well. The game also has a 2 player VS mode, as well as a race mode where you try to get to a goal as fast as you can. The game also has a cool Monty Python animation style in its cutscenes, and it has some oddball visual humor as well. It works well in Single Player, and the AI is pretty fair, but if you want to get some more legs out of the game it's worth it to play the VS mode with a friend.

Posted: July 15, 2016
												... What can be said about Rock of Ages? If I could describe this game in one word, it would be "silly". In the next few lines, you'll understand why.The plot/concept of this game is a unique take on the famous Greek myth of Sisyphus, a man condemned to Tartarus and punished to roll a boulder up a hill that keeps rolling back down for all eternity. In this game, Sisyphus has had enough, and uses his accursed boulder to escape and flatten all of time itself. From then on, it becomes a cross between a Ski-Ball game and a Tower Defense, in which you are sent to different courses modeled after different historical figures and are challenged to squish them. Gameplay is divided between two turns: Construction and Rolling. During the Construction phase, you can put up obstacles with earned points to slow down and impede your opponent's boulder, by either blocking the way or knocking them off course. Rolling Phase has you roll your boulder down the opponent's course (which has also been furnished with defenses), and break down the doors to squish your opponent. Like I said. Silly.Sure, this game can get repetitive at times, but it's still a fun little bit of weirdness to lighten up your day. Plus, every level begins and ends with 'Dies Irae' and 'Ode to Joy'. It's quirky good fun, and a fun challenge to boot. I give this game a 7/10 recommendation, just for some jolly good fun. Besides: where else can you crush Leonardo Da Vinci with a smiling boulder?

Posted: June 24, 2015
												Rock of Ages has the kind of base concept you'd hear and say, "hmm, that'd make a fun flash game".As you can probably tell, this isn't a flash game.You guide your rolling stone around a winding course and hit the enemy gate until it dies. But you have a gate and the enemy has a Brian Jones! But you can both place down defences after your Ian Stewards have been smashed! And then you can use your leftover currency to buy better Mick Jaggers!It's fun, it's as slow or fast paced as you want it be, and it has a challenging difficulty curve.The cutscenes in story are silly little gags to the layman, and chock-a-block with jokes for the history nerds. The Rock of Ages is called the Rock of AGES for a reason!I'd heartily recommend this game for a romp with your friends too. Strangely enough, latency lags both players, even when they're playing with their own individual courses. I thought the core design of war mode would have countered that.Good game, I like it a whole bunch, pick it up when you need to fill some time.

Posted: June 25, 2015
												This game is very well-rounded, and an excellent source of entertainment if you get bored, can't find the motivation to start up a more complex game like Europa Universalis or Kerbal Space Program, and just want to smash something fast.That's after you beat the campaign of course, which is fun in of itself. There are three main modes a single person would be interested in, and the same for multiplayer. There's War, Obstacle Course, Time Trial, and Skeeboulder. The singleplayer campaign consists entirely of War games throughout all the maps and five different 'ages', Sparta, (characterized by orange and black clay-jar carvings as an art style) the Middle Ages, (reminds me of ancient tapestries) the Renaissance, (with both roman architecture and a lot of marble) Baroque France, (very blue, very fancy) and Spain. (a very dark and gruesome Spain, however)I still pop in almost every day to play a few rounds of obstacle course, and while the campaign won't last forever there's plenty there to play for quite some time.

Posted: January 18, 2015
												I have now completed main story and I gotta say that I do love this game.When rock of ages started poppin up in featured and recomended games I didn't think much of it. The picture seemed too uhm... not special and attention catching.Then it came on sale one weekend while i was looking at my quence and it came up so I took a look at it.I fell in love with this game as soon as I saw the trailer!It looked like it was pulled out of a Monty Phyton movie or the Flying circus series. Both the cut scenes and levels.So I bought it and played as soon as it downloaded. Even at the full price it is worth every penny.However I feel the story is a little short. Might be that or I just love it too much and want more of it.But I enjoyed this game alot and I loved the graphics and soundtrack. I loved my rock. Especially when I saw the option of choosing its face! So now my rock has the cutest little smiley face.And now the good and bad.possitive:* Easy to play even for n00bies.* Cute rocks* Great and funny levels as well as cutscenes.* Gandalf was run over by your rock in a cutscene.* 4th wall breaking by a certain someone.* Awesome and fun soundtack.* When you win you get the most satisfying splat noise ever as you run over your enemy.* There was paid alot of attention to detail. Even the ground has patterns and everything looks amazing.* The price is also very resonable for what you get.* Trollface stone, snowball stone, pumpkin and a block. How is that unenjoyable?* The "Nooooeh" scream the people make is halarious.* Actually there is historical value as well as jokes.* The entertainment i had and will still have with this game is amazing. I have laughed and smiled alot.Negative:* I would like more levels.* The last couple of levels in a row had the same music. It was good music but still...Who would love this game:* People who like Monty Phyton.* People who loves funny/weird games.* People who likes a somewhat comical wiev at history and historical persons.Who would hate this game:* Peoplw who don't find Monty Phyton funny at all.* People who don't do weird or funny.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												A very silly and very fun game about rolling boulders on an obstacle course to destroy your opponents base. Each person places defenses to protect their base while rolling their boulder towards the other one's base. Not a complex premise, which makes it very easy to jump right in. The single player storyline is very humourous and the visuals are Monty Python-esque and quite comical. Overall, a great little game to sink a bit of time into here and there.8/10 - IT ROCKS

Posted: June 14, 2015
												Go get your balls to the wall man.It's a satirical game where you control an upgradable ball that smashes into cows, elephans and screaming cardboard people in an attempt to reach the gate at the end of the track, break it down, and squash the enemy player, usually represented by some historical or mythological figure, hiding behind it. If you are not entirely sure if you understand what I just said, that's fine - means you don't do drugs. If you do happen to look upon this game while under the effect of LSD or other hallucinogenic drugs, I am sure it will all make sense to you.The game mechanics are quite clever. 2 tracks, each with some branching. A gate on each end. Behind the gate - the player. Each player has a ball they must roll through the enemy track and hit the enemy gate with as much force as possible. Defence structures on the track damage the ball, breaking off it's mass. When the ball is destroyed or reaches the gate at the end, the player has some time before a new one is built to reinforce their track with defensive structures. A game ends when one player crushes another's gate and rolls over their avatar behind it.This is a fun game to play at parties, especially if you are short on weed or value your health yet still want to f*ck with people's minds. Also if you think a 4 ton stone boulder can squash a cow - you are wrong. Cow>stone. OOOOOOOOOO/10(those are balls)If this game was an accurate representation of history, it would be a pretty good representation.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												This game is awesome! If you want the perfect multiplayer game (both local and online) to play with friends, you can't go wrong with this game. Split screen is absolutley where the game shines though, nothing beats the enjoyment you get when you totally destroy your friend and he gets red with anger. If you want to know what the game is about, or how the game works...well that's kind of hard to explain. You're basically duelling each other by sending a rock to the other player's door as hard as you can. The opposing player creates blockades to try and stop you. So there's kind of two phases you need to master, building blockades and rolling your rock to destroy your opponents door. It sounds totally crazy and weird, but that's a part of the game too. You should just buy it and play, you won't regret it.Oh, and btw, I have played this game over 30 hours on PS3, so yes, I have a lot of experience with this game, and I can tell you this game is worth your money.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Like a lot of ACE games, Rock of Ages is a diamond in the rough, and well worth the price of admission (especially how often it's on sale and how deeply discounted).The premise is fairly simple: you roll a giant boulder through an obstacle course trying to mash in a set of gates at the opposite gate.It has a great sense of humor, interesting graphics, and mechanics that are at least something different.In my opinion the only downside is the combination of building defenses for your opponent along with trying to run through theirs: you can only place obstacles while you're waiting for your next boulder and this is also the only time you can try and pinpoint-catapult the enemy. Annoyingly, the computer opponents in single player seem to be able to catapult you the entire time (because of course) and have ridiculous accuracy, which can be frustrating.So it's not perfect, but it's often only a few dollars, and is easily worth that, if not quite a few more.

Posted: April 20, 2015
												Rock of Ages is a platformer/race/tower defense game where you control a ball similar to games like Torquing (Funorb), Super Monkey Ball and various recent marble/ball themed puzzle games on Steam.The game is a bit silly and sometimes frustrating, but otherwise a very fun game that makes you feel achieved after beating it's challenges. Posted: April 11, 2015
												I REALLY enjoyed this game. There should be a sequel or at least an expansion pack!!Pros:- It's such a unique concept- The music is really awesome- The game makes me laugh - There is a ton of replayability because of the different game modes, as well as possible defenses you can experiment with in the campaign mode.- The artwork is really cool- The sound FX crack me up- Gameplay mechanics are really good- Great level design- Controls are easy- TRICK JUMPS!!!!Cons:- Obstacle course mode is way too easy- Enemy rock AI needs to have difficulty levels and be improved (this is the main reason why obstacle course mode is way too easy)- There's a bug that screws up camera/controls after many relaunches in time trial mode leading to needing to restart the level again from the time trial menu <-- this is minor- Finding yourself in the time trial universal scores list for each level is difficult <-- this is minor- Catapults are a bit OP and/or some units take up too many squares, which sort of forces the player to stick to finding a pinch point and creating a blockade of towers with catapults behind them on harder maps because each of these only takes up 1 square <-- This can make the game a little bit monotonous, but on the flip side it may encourage more experimentation with different defenses on another playthrough so I'm 50/50 on this one.All in all though this game is seriously awesome, quirky and heavily addictive fun that will see you finishing it in only a few sittings, so I wholeheartedly recommend it!!!

Posted: September 8, 2011
												I bought this simply because it was cheap and the "Rock beats everything" promo amused me. Surprisingly, it's a pretty fun game to play and it's appealing in both visuals and control.It plays like a strange combination of tower defense, and reverse katamari. Take control of your boulder and mow down enemy towers and units on the way to their castle gate, while at the same time maintaining your own defenses from THEIR boulder. Online play is enjoyable when you can get an opponent, and the music, humor, references and 'storyline' are pretty good. Check it out if you have 10 USD to burn.

Posted: July 12, 2012
												Possibly my new favorite racing game, and I don't even like racing games! Er, well, Rock of Ages is a humorous title with some stellar art (the use of classical pieces does in fact remind me of [and I know others have said this] Terry Gilliam's work) and fun gameplay. The multiplayer shines especially in obstacle course mode, which is essentially a race, and war, which mixes in a little strategy. Thus far into the game, the only irritation is that the obstacle course multiplayer only allows two players; I could see this being ridiculously fun with more players! I do recommend this game, especially if the price is low.

Posted: February 8, 2015
												Rock of ages a great game. It has multiple fun modes and a hilarious art style that make it stand out. It came out in 2011 but it still has great graphics. The only problem is that not much people play this game so its hard to go on multiplayer. The majority of players got it in 2011 when it was on sale but this great game needs more players. The game is amazing but it can get a little repetitive.I got the game after watching Total Biscuit and Jack septic eye playing it. My final problem of the game is that it can be less enjoyable if you don't have a high end computer. It is slightly laggy and the graphics aren't as great but its still a good gameI rate it a 9/10 and all it lacks are some more players and maybe a sequel or an expansion.It is unlikely there will be a expansion since it's so old but a sequel would be great and the game would become popular quickly it is also 6.99 which is a bit expensive but if you have extra money to spend get this game its worth it.

Posted: June 18, 2015
												Archangel Michael slew a dragon, then proceeded to party down, until I flattened him with a flaming boulder/10.Easily the best historical figure flattening simulation I've ever had the pleasure of playing.  Escape hell and impose your boulder-enforced will on some of historys most memorable figures.  Either that, or run time trials with a STONE CUBE.Lots of fun.  The art style is funny - based on classical art, animated ala Monty Python, telling ridiculous stories with wry humor.  If you don't know, go find out why we all ate Robin's minstrel.It's like a racing game whose key mechanic is control lag.  That's a positive, by the way.  You are, after all, Sisyphus.The novelty may wear out, but those impossible boulder leaps and terrified squeals of epic characters still amuse.

Posted: April 26, 2014
												Sisyphus, an immortal Greek Titan, has a job to do. For the rest of eternity he must push a giant boulder up a hill in Hades until a magical enchantment causes it to roll back down to the bottom again. Understandably enough, Sisyphus eventually decides this un-life isnât for him and swiftly breaks out of Hades, taking his giant boulder and some Titan buddies with him.Rock of Ages is a hilariously chaotic mixture of Insane Obstacle Course and Tower Defence, alternating between guiding your boulder into the enemy gates to break them down, and building medieval weaponry to stop your rival boulder from breaking your own gates. Itâs a genuine pleasure to watch your hastily erected dynamite finish just in time to blast your opponent completely off-course with white-knuckle timing.As you progress through the campaign by massively interrupting famous European historical events, you unlock more Tower Defence items to stymie your opponents efforts and more rock types to destroy the enemy gates which does an excellent job of keeping the gameplay of Rock of Ages fresh and delightfully experimental; will only using War Mammoths stop your opponent wrecking your gates more than wall after wall of dynamite?Rock of Ages also shines in the cutscenes between levels with both a unique art style and hugely funny direction. Famous characters and events are played out on screen in a 2D mumble-speech cinematic, with the famous opponents (normally accurate, although Plato and Aristotle probably never came back from the dead) highlighted in a massively dramatic way. It brilliantly furthers the light-hearted and joyfully silly theme.It quickly becomes apparent when playing Rock of Ages that it is a game wholeheartedly about the joy of play. Each level is short enough that progress is never too far away and you will never guess what the game is going to throw at you next. With a depth of silliness that will bring a smile to any face Rock of Ages is a pure joy to play and happily provides many hours of shameless fun.

Posted: February 21, 2012
												It's like a Monty Python journeys through art history... the game. Rock of Ages is super fun, the controls feel good and the game runs really well. The art direction and aesthetic of the game are amazing and really capture the art style of the periods you travel through. There's fun little customizations to your hero and ball, and the overall depth of the gameplay was more than I had initially anticipated. It has an enjoyable multiplayer component that feels natural and fun and not just tacked on. All this combines to create a game that is silly, light hearted and just plain enjoyable. Rock of Ages is undoubtly worth the asking price, and is a great game for any type of gamer  of any experince level, it's very approachable and easy to pick up and a lot of fun. GO BUY IT! :]

Posted: July 15, 2016
												... What can be said about Rock of Ages? If I could describe this game in one word, it would be "silly". In the next few lines, you'll understand why.The plot/concept of this game is a unique take on the famous Greek myth of Sisyphus, a man condemned to Tartarus and punished to roll a boulder up a hill that keeps rolling back down for all eternity. In this game, Sisyphus has had enough, and uses his accursed boulder to escape and flatten all of time itself. From then on, it becomes a cross between a Ski-Ball game and a Tower Defense, in which you are sent to different courses modeled after different historical figures and are challenged to squish them. Gameplay is divided between two turns: Construction and Rolling. During the Construction phase, you can put up obstacles with earned points to slow down and impede your opponent's boulder, by either blocking the way or knocking them off course. Rolling Phase has you roll your boulder down the opponent's course (which has also been furnished with defenses), and break down the doors to squish your opponent. Like I said. Silly.Sure, this game can get repetitive at times, but it's still a fun little bit of weirdness to lighten up your day. Plus, every level begins and ends with 'Dies Irae' and 'Ode to Joy'. It's quirky good fun, and a fun challenge to boot. I give this game a 7/10 recommendation, just for some jolly good fun. Besides: where else can you crush Leonardo Da Vinci with a smiling boulder?

Posted: December 17, 2014
												Score: 8/10This is essentially a bowling game merged with tower defense. Your goal is to break down the door on the other side of the map with your giant boulder and crush your opponent who is beyond the door while your enemy attempts to do the same. You can upgrade your boulder as well as put up defenses to protect your door. The boulders can be knocked off the map as well as destroyed causing you to have to remake the boulder and send it on it's merry way again. This game also has local co-op so it makes a great party game.

Honestly, thats what made me seal the deal when I saw this very meme oriented monty python humorous game that uses a tower defense and attack as its main gameplay. Do not get me wrong, there are other game modes, two other game modes to be exact and they are just as fun as the main one. The fun to be had in this game is with your friends so get them to buy the game and prepare to have some enjoyable evenings.This is a multiplayer game by all means, so do not buy it if you wont be playing with friends.

Posted: July 4, 2012
												Everyone must play this game at least once before they die. Extremely silly, funny and enjoyable little indie game. It has a certain Monty Pythonesque humour and it does induce some strong desire to crush everything, that's basically all you ever need to know about this game.The gameplay is pretty easy and simple, you control a massive boulder with WASD keys and jump over or towards things with Spacebar. Your objective is usually to destroy the enemy's gates and crush the git into a gooey mess. And in the meantime you can build some defenses to slow down enemy's boulder such as catapults, cows, elephants, towers and fans. You can also upgrade your boulder with the money you make from destroying things. There are of course bonus levels and boss fights too. It's all good fun. The game also supports multiplayer, haven't gotten into that so I can't say much.If you want a small, cheap and fun game to waste some time and have a laugh, this would be definitely the best game to go for.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game is simply amazing. You play as a giant rock, the goal is to slam into the enemy castle door as hard as you can, while building tower defensy structures to prevent the enemy from doing the same. You roll trough the ages, every chapter brings you to a new era of human history, the twist is everything is represented in the art style of the time. From ancient greeks to rococo, with music to match. The cutscenes are also hilarious. And you get to fight historical figures, real and fictionnal.Get it.

Posted: January 4, 2012
												While Rock of Ages isn't a particularly long game, it's 100% entertainment for the entire course of your playtime. The difficulty is well-balanced so frustration is practically non-existent, the unique blend of tower defense/strategy and... Super Monkey Ball and Monty Python is certainly something. Very weird, very humorous, very engaging. At not even 10 bucks a pop, this is a game you seriously shouldn't miss.

												I wasn't sure of this game at a glance, so I bought it with the Christmas deal that's running as I write this. Highly, highly recommend it. It's a great mixture of strategy and...I'm not sure what to call it, action? More accurately would be strategy and rolling. At first, you may not see the appeal, but the game has a great sense of humor, along with smooth gameplay, a fun art style, and good music. Definitely suggest this if you like thinking and smashing things. Which may not seem to go together, but let me assure you, they do, and great fun ensues as a result.

It usually takes three times trough the course to break the enemy's gate and win the round.For me it sometimes was a bit confusing and the controls did not react as I expected... still not too bad of a game.

Posted: September 3, 2014
												The world premier virtual bowling tower defence where you get to flatten historical figures and battle mythological beasts. It also boasts a very much Monty Python inspired aesthetic and sense of humor. The challenging campaign is enough to keep the "just one more" attitude. While I haven't tried the online multiplayer or the split screen mode, I have had a go at the alternate gamemodes and found them a nice distraction from the main game. The game also allows for you to play as any historical figure you have defeated and use a variety of different bolders, my favourite is the Block of Ages. All in all the game has a challenging and interresting campaign, with the welcome option of multiplayer.

Posted: August 26, 2014
												A very fun local multiplayer game, great for playing with friends. The game is filled top to bottom with humorous touches, and it still manages to be very strategic without compremising the silliness of it's core mechanic. On top of that, it has a great art style. Once you get past the first level it lacks a proper tutorial, but the mechanics are easy to pick up even without proper instuctions. For the price, it's a great value.

If you love 'Monty Python and the Holy Grail' then this definitely belongs in your library. If you also like tower defense games where you are also the attacker, this is a pretty cool game. There are a few pretty challenging levels early on, so it definitely doesn't mess around despite it's humorous exterior.

It has some replayability, but (in my opinion) only in co-op as there aren't almost any players online..  and the local co-op sadly requires 2 controllers.9/10

												I've sorted this game into my 'Arcade' section of my steam library because it reminds me of just that: a souped-up Marble Madness. There is a lot more to it, including tower defense and RTS mechanics, but it doesn't every feel like you've moved beyond the simple jump-and-roll mechanic... which is a good thing. Rather, those components of gameplay just feel like accoutrements to enhance your experiences.Not enough can be said about the art style of ACE Studios' games though; you might hate the Monty Pythonesque humor but I enjoy the unique setting they always give their games.

Posted: February 2, 2015
												Rock of ages is a weird but fun indie game, it takes the concept of katamari roll into things and tower defense, build stuff in the path to halt enemy boulders and combines it decently well.The soundtrack is really fun to nice to listen to, and the graphics while simplistic are quite good.In this game you are some sort of slave for the gods until you get angry and decide to take the fight back at them, defeating many legendary icons along the way like carlomagne, leonidas, vlad (dracula) and more, all of the accompanied with very funny cutscenes with games and movie references (castlevania,lord of the rings,etc).There's several kind of boulders each doing different amount of damage to the enemy gate and as you progress you get better stuff to defend your mountain, taller towers, better catapults, TNT, giant animals and catapult precise shots.While very fun to play after about an hour it gets boring and repetitive, specially since the same strategy works over and over.Worth the full price? no, but if you can grab it at 3$ or less price go ahead and buy it.
